div.p:
SCHISM, (from the Greek, σχισμα, cliſt, fiſſure), in its general acceptation ſignines divisioη or ſeparation; but is chiefly uſed in ſpeaking of ſeparations happening
from diverſity of opinions among people of the fame religion and faith.
Thus we lay the ſchiſm of the ten tribes of Judah and Benjamin, the schi ſm of the Perſians from the Turks and other Mahometans, &c.

Among eccleſiaſtical authors, the great ſchiſm of the Weſt is that which happened in the times of Clement VII. and Urban VI. which divided the church for 40 or 50 years, and was at length ended by the election of Martin V. at the council of Conſtance.

The Romaniſts number 34 ſchiſms in their church. —They beſtow the name English ſchiſm on the reformation of religion in this kingdom Thoſe of the church of England apply the term ſchiſm to the ſeparation of the nonconformiſts, viz. the preſhyterians, independents, and anabaptiſts, for a further reformation.
